description: From Middle English pisse (noun) and pissen (verb), from Old French pissier, possibly from Vulgar Latin *pīssiāre, probably of echoic origin. Compare Old Norse pissa (“to urinate, piss”).

entries.meaning: (now vulgar slang, usually uncountable) Urine. [from 14th c.]
examples: This toilet is disgusting. There's piss all over the floor.

entries.meaning: (vulgar, slang, countable) The act of urinating. [from 19th c.]
(vulgar, slang, countable and uncountable) Alcoholic beverage, especially of inferior quality. [from 20th c.]
examples: ‘Want some advice?’ I said. ‘Stay off the piss. You won't want to be handling this kind of thing with a hangover.’

verbs.description: piss (third-person singular simple present pisses, present participle pissing, simple past and past participle pissed)

examples: When I got home I found a drunk pissing in my doorway.

entries.meaning: (transitive, mildly vulgar) To discharge as or with the urine.
(transitive, chiefly Britain, mildly vulgar) To achieve easily.
(transitive, intransitive, mildly vulgar) To rain heavily.
examples: She spent that night under her sheet of polythene and 'somehow managed to get only half wet', waking up the next morning to find that 'it had absolutely pissed  down through the night'.
